name: 4-chloro-2-methylanisole
Reason: 4-chloro-2-methylanisole has a chlorine atom and a methyl group attached to a benzene ring. The chlorine atom is a halogen, which increases the melting point due to its electronegativity and the formation of dipole-dipole interactions. The methyl group increases the molecular weight and volume, which might slightly raise the melting point. The melting point of 4-chloro-2-methylanisole can be estimated by comparing it to the melting point of 4-chloroanisole, which has a melting point of 34.5°C. The methyl group in 4-chloro-2-methylanisole increases the molecular weight by 14 amu compared to 4-chloroanisole. The melting point increase due to the methyl group can be estimated by comparing the melting point difference between ethylbenzene (136.2°C) and toluene (110.6°C). The melting point difference is 25.6°C, which is approximately 1.83°C per methyl group. The melting point of 4-chloro-2-methylanisole can be estimated as follows: 34.5°C (4-chloroanisole) + 1.83°C/methyl group × 1 methyl group = 36.33°C.
